Yes, removed.

nodes.bodyText: This could be PlannerExpressionWithPredicate instead of LogicalFilterExpression, right? But that would require a withOtherPredicate method on PlannerExpressionWithPredicate
Yes, it could be (subject to the contrast you described). I'm not sure whether this is desirable but it's worth thinking about in the future.
The only implementation of this is now GroupExpressionRef right? Is there a reason to keep the interface around?

Yes, that's right. There's a reason, but it might not be a good one.
The reason to keep it is in the Javadoc:

This interface is used mostly as an (admittedly surmountable) barrier to rules mutating bound references directly.

The idea is that it provides some kind of discouragement to a rule writer who tries to invoke the various methods in GroupExpressionRef, which will totally confuse the planner. I'm not sure if the overhead is worth it, though.

nodes.bodyText: Consider to have a List<QueryPredicate> here. I am assuming that ANDs are just encoded within the QueryPredicate, but it seems to be a nice property to be a able to move the AND terms underneath around into other RelationExpressions. Sometimes, it might be even beneficial to move these terms into multiple expressions where a QueryPredicate term can exist and (e.g. for reapplication purposes, etc.). In those cases it would become necessary to relate those QueryPredicate instances in some way and having a list of AND terms here let's you do that just easier I think.

nodes.bodyText:
Yes, AND here is encoded using AndPredicate.
I agree that it would be pretty nice to have an "implicit top-level AND". In particular, it would let us get rid of the conjunct/non-conjunct distinction in the planner rules.
For the sake of review, I'd like to make this a follow-up PR (which should be fairly short and focussed). I created #939 to track this.

nodes.bodyText: Shouldn't this be done for Bindable? I mean you do allow T extends Bindable in the class definition, contains() for a Bindable that is no. RelationalExpression would always be `false.

Ah, good catch! This is only used to implement the Memo data structure, so it should really only contain things that can be memoized (i.e., RelationalExpressions). This looks like an artifact of how I did my (largely automated) refactoring. I've changed it here and verified that the code still builds.
Consider renaming!
Good idea! Changed to RelationalExpressionPointerSet.

This is a general comment re: this class. Consider using Guava Equivalence class, which comes with a subclass Equivalence.Identity which I think would eliminate the reason for the Wrapper class. Also, there is IdentityHashMap which can help here.

Ah, thanks for the pointer (pun somewhat intended)! I remember looking for this a long time ago and not finding it, but clearly my Google-fu was inadequate.
I would rather do this in another PR, so I filed #940 to track this work.
How do you now explore the e.g. QueryPredicate expressions hanging off RelationalExpressions?

We don't. If we wanted to do that, we'd need to write this as a rule on a RelationalExpressionWithPredicate and then manipulate the QueryPredicate manually. We can consider adding custom logic for exploring predicates (but without memoization?) in the future, I suppose.
Will we not ever descend into predicates, etc.?
Correct, because we can't memoize them after this change.
use unqualified names if possible

Our style checker requires us to use qualified names here because RelationalExpression is in a different package. If we import it but only use it in a Javadoc, the unused import linter rule gets upset.
I'd love for this to be fixed, but I wasn't successful last time I tried (some years ago).
Same here.
See above.
This seems to contradict with the purpose of the property as stated in the java doc of the class. Are you counting QueryComponent or QueryPredicate?

Ah, good point. If we wanted to implement this, we couldn't use the infrastructure for PlannerProperty anymore.
On the other hand, it looks like this is dead code, so I've deleted it instead.
